content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    question_start = "## Question"
    answer_start = "## Answer"

    sections = split(md, "\n\n## Question\n\n")

    question = strip(sections[1])
    sections = split(sections[2], "\n\n## Answer\n\n")
    answer = strip(sections[1])

    return (question, answer)
end
```

This function splits the input markdown text into sections based on the presence of `## Question` and `## Answer` headers. It then extracts the text in the corresponding sections, strips any leading spaces and newlines, and returns the question and answer as a tuple. Note that this assumes that there is exactly one section for each question and answer, and that the first section after the given headers is the one with the actual question or answer. If more complex formatting or additional sections are allowed, the function might need to be updated accordingly.
